readings.title: Invictus
readings.author: William Ernest Henley
readings.excerpt: I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.

readings.title: If—
readings.author: Rudyard Kipling
readings.excerpt: If you can keep your head when all about you are losing theirs and blaming it on you...

readings.title: The Road Not Taken
readings.author: Robert Frost
readings.excerpt: Two roads diverged in a wood, and I— I took the one less traveled by, and that has made all the difference.

readings.title: Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night
readings.author: Dylan Thomas
readings.excerpt: Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

readings.title: Ozymandias
readings.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
readings.excerpt: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair! Nothing beside remains.

readings.title: The Charge of the Light Brigade
readings.author: Alfred, Lord Tennyson
readings.excerpt: Theirs not to make reply, theirs not to reason why, theirs but to do and die.

readings.title: Still I Rise
readings.author: Maya Angelou
readings.excerpt: You may shoot me with your words, you may cut me with your eyes... but still, like air, I'll rise.

readings.title: The Waste Land
readings.author: T.S. Eliot
readings.excerpt: April is the cruellest month, breeding lilacs out of the dead land, mixing memory and desire.

readings.title: Song of Myself
readings.author: Walt Whitman
readings.excerpt: I celebrate myself, and sing myself, and what I assume you shall assume.

readings.title: The Raven
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary... Quoth the Raven 'Nevermore.'

readings.title: Howl
readings.author: Allen Ginsberg
readings.excerpt: I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness, starving hysterical naked.

readings.title: I Hear America Singing
readings.author: Walt Whitman
readings.excerpt: I hear America singing, the varied carols I hear.

readings.title: Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening
readings.author: Robert Frost
readings.excerpt: The woods are lovely, dark and deep, but I have promises to keep, and miles to go before I sleep.

readings.title: O Captain! My Captain!
readings.author: Walt Whitman
readings.excerpt: O Captain! my Captain! our fearful trip is done, the ship has weather'd every rack, the prize we sought is won.

readings.title: Dulce et Decorum Est
readings.author: Wilfred Owen
readings.excerpt: Bent double, like old beggars under sacks, knock-kneed, coughing like hags, we cursed through sludge.

readings.title: The Second Coming
readings.author: William Butler Yeats
readings.excerpt: Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold; mere anarchy is loosed upon the world.

readings.title: Annabel Lee
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: It was many and many a year ago, in a kingdom by the sea, that a maiden there lived whom you may know by the name of Annabel Lee.

readings.title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock
readings.author: T.S. Eliot
readings.excerpt: Let us go then, you and I, when the evening is spread out against the sky.

readings.title: The Man in the Arena
readings.author: Theodore Roosevelt
readings.excerpt: It is not the critic who counts; not the man who points out how the strong man stumbles...

readings.title: The Tell-Tale Heart
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: TRUE! — nervous — very, very dreadfully nervous I had been and am; but why will you say that I am mad?

readings.title: The Cask of Amontillado
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: The thousand injuries of Fortunato I had borne as I best could, but when he ventured upon insult I vowed revenge.

readings.title: The Gift of the Magi
readings.author: O. Henry
readings.excerpt: One dollar and eighty-seven cents. That was all. And sixty cents of it was in pennies.

readings.title: The Yellow Wallpaper
readings.author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
readings.excerpt: It is very seldom that mere ordinary people like John and myself secure ancestral halls for the summer.

readings.title: The Most Dangerous Game
readings.author: Richard Connell
readings.excerpt: 'Off there to the right — somewhere — is a large island,' said Whitney. 'It's rather a mystery—'

readings.title: An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge
readings.author: Ambrose Bierce
readings.excerpt: A man stood upon a railroad bridge in northern Alabama, looking down into the swift water twenty feet below.

readings.title: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
readings.author: Mark Twain
readings.excerpt: In compliance with the request of a friend of mine... I called on good-natured, garrulous old Simon Wheeler.

readings.title: The Story of an Hour
readings.author: Kate Chopin
readings.excerpt: Knowing that Mrs. Mallard was afflicted with a heart trouble, great care was taken to break to her as gently as possible the news of her husband's death.

readings.title: To Build a Fire
readings.author: Jack London
readings.excerpt: Day had broken cold and grey, exceedingly cold and grey, when the man turned aside from the main Yukon trail.

readings.title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
readings.author: Washington Irving
readings.excerpt: In the bosom of one of those spacious coves which indent the eastern shore of the Hudson...

readings.title: Bartleby, the Scrivener
readings.author: Herman Melville
readings.excerpt: I am a rather elderly man. The nature of my avocations for the last thirty years has brought me into more than ordinary contact with what would seem an interesting and somewhat singular set of men.

readings.title: The Metamorphosis
readings.author: Franz Kafka
readings.excerpt: One morning, when Gregor Samsa woke from troubled dreams, he found himself transformed in his bed into a horrible vermin.

readings.title: A Christmas Carol
readings.author: Charles Dickens
readings.excerpt: Marley was dead: to begin with. There is no doubt whatever about that.

readings.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
readings.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
readings.excerpt: To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name.

readings.title: Heart of Darkness
readings.author: Joseph Conrad
readings.excerpt: The Nellie, a cruising yawl, swung to her anchor without a flutter of the sails, and was at rest.

readings.title: The Call of the Wild
readings.author: Jack London
readings.excerpt: Buck did not read the newspapers, or he would have known that trouble was brewing.

readings.title: The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
readings.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
readings.excerpt: Mr. Utterson the lawyer was a man of a rugged countenance that was never lighted by a smile.

readings.title: The Lottery
readings.author: Shirley Jackson
readings.excerpt: The morning of June 27th was clear and sunny, with the fresh warmth of a full-summer day.

readings.title: A Good Man Is Hard to Find
readings.author: Flannery O'Connor
readings.excerpt: The grandmother didn't want to go to Florida. She wanted to visit some of her connections in east Tennessee.

readings.title: The Open Boat
readings.author: Stephen Crane
readings.excerpt: None of them knew the colour of the sky. Their eyes glanced level, and were fastened upon the waves that swept toward them.

readings.title: The Necklace
readings.author: Guy de Maupassant
readings.excerpt: She was one of those pretty and charming girls born, as though fate had blundered over her, into a family of artisans.

readings.title: Paul's Case
readings.author: Willa Cather
readings.excerpt: It was Paul's afternoon to appear before the faculty of the Pittsburgh High School to account for his various misdemeanours.

readings.title: The Pit and the Pendulum
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: I was sick — sick unto death with that long agony; and when they at length unbound me, and I was permitted to sit, I felt that my senses were leaving me.

readings.title: The Fall of the House of Usher
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: During the whole of a dull, dark, and soundless day in the autumn of the year... I had been passing alone, on horseback, through a singularly dreary tract of country.

readings.title: Meditations (Book 2)
readings.author: Marcus Aurelius
readings.excerpt: Begin the morning by saying to thyself, I shall meet with the busy-body, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial.

readings.title: The Art of War
readings.author: Sun Tzu
readings.excerpt: The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.

readings.title: Walden (Chapter 1: Economy)
readings.author: Henry David Thoreau
readings.excerpt: I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life.

readings.title: Self-Reliance
readings.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
readings.excerpt: Trust thyself: every heart vibrates to that iron string. Accept the place the divine providence has found for you.

readings.title: Civil Disobedience
readings.author: Henry David Thoreau
readings.excerpt: That government is best which governs least.

readings.title: The Gettysburg Address
readings.author: Abraham Lincoln
readings.excerpt: Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent, a new nation, conceived in Liberty.

readings.title: The Prince
readings.author: Niccolò Machiavelli
readings.excerpt: All states, all powers, that have held and hold rule over men have been and are either republics or principalities.

readings.title: The Masque of the Red Death
readings.author: Edgar Allan Poe
readings.excerpt: The 'Red Death' had long devastated the country. No pestilence had ever been so fatal, or so hideous.
